Title.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the association between neostigmine and postoperative atelectasis, and other complications in elderly patients undergoing laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPD).

Trial_Design.evidence: This single-center retrospective cohort study included elderly patients who underwent LPD between 2019 and 2022.

Participants.evidence: This single-center retrospective cohort study included elderly patients who underwent LPD between 2019 and 2022.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were divided into two groups based on exposure to neostigmine: the neostigmine reversal group (exposed) and the control group (not exposed).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the association between neostigmine and postoperative atelectasis, and other complications in elderly patients undergoing laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPD).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was the incidence of atelectasis within the first 3 postoperative days.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 501 patients initially included, 302 were successfully matched after PSM at a 1:5 ratio, comprising 89 patients in the neostigmine reversal group and 213 in the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 501 patients initially included, 302 were successfully matched after PSM at a 1:5 ratio, comprising 89 patients in the neostigmine reversal group and 213 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Compared to the control group, the incidence of postoperative atelectasis was lower in the neostigmine reversal group (OR 0.43 [95% CI 0.24–0.75], p = 0.003) in elderly patients undergoing elective LPD.
